title: Search bar in a shared space

comments.body:
Hi,

Thank for your issue.

We don't have this behaviour on our infra and this is because I see we added this annotation on the jobs:
```
migrateJobAnnotations:
    argocd.argoproj.io/hook: PreSync
    argocd.argoproj.io/hook-delete-policy: HookSucceeded
```

We should probably add them to the default values.

comments.body: The backend expose to the frontend the creation and updated date. Pick the one you want :-)

@lunika I bet what we want is to display the real creation date of the file. Let's say we have a file on our local disk created 2 years ago, uploading it to Drive today. We want to see "Feb 2024" instead of 2026 in this area: What I suggest is to create a new attribute `Item.file_created_at` in DB that takes the real file creation date. WDYT @lunika @lunika ?

comments.body: [Here is my proposal](https://www.figma.com/design/XDjWHDLIiNY4mtpyj21EVK/Drive?node-id=12171-15674&t=DXkTXHvOqgv84Wq9-1), validated by @PanchoutNathan
This PR provides foundation for this: https://github.com/suitenumerique/drive/pull/395

After investigating, here is my understanding:
We need to add a new `shared_with_me` action in `ItemViewSet`.
This endpoint should return only the files that are shared directly with the current user ‚Äî 
meaning the user is not the creator, and the user does not access the file through a shared 
folder, but instead has direct/standalone access to the file.
Shared folders or workspaces should not be included, since they already appear in the shared 
workspaces list.

If this is correct, I‚Äôd like to work on it. Can the issue be assigned to me? @lunika

Hi @enansaif 

I opened this issue to remind me to investigate it later :-)

I have to discuss it with the internal team, maybe this discussion can be public if you want to participate.
Thanks for the update. Just let me know when the internal team has defined the expected behavior, I‚Äôll follow along or contribute wherever useful.
Will be fixed with https://github.com/suitenumerique/drive/pull/383

title: Impossible to open share modal on mobile

comments.body:
Hi! I explored this issue and was initially having trouble reproducing it.
Here are the steps I used, in case it helps anyone:
[1] Create an item from account A.
[2] Make that item public and copy share link.
[3] Log into account B and open that link.
[4] That item will appear on Public Space section.
A commit has been added in the PR #375 fixing this issue https://github.com/suitenumerique/drive/pull/375/commits/3e318013ccde05a1f8b6b77e9fa06492ebc1819a
This is going to be fixed with https://github.com/suitenumerique/drive/pull/383

comments.body: Fully agreed!

Hi! Really exciting to see someone mentioning RAG + OCR + doc Q&A in one place ‚Äî this combo is powerful but notoriously tricky to implement right.

Just wanted to say: we‚Äôre the first project ever starred by the creator of Tesseract.js (yes, that OCR legend).
Here‚Äôs the proof ‚Äî nothing fancy, just the raw link: (we are WFGY)

üëâ https://github.com/bijection?tab=stars

We‚Äôve spent the past months solving exactly this intersection:

    OCR inputs (PDFs, images, scans)

    Seamless RAG ingestion

    Stable, multi-turn reasoning

If your team is moving in this direction and ever runs into weird OCR behavior, token injection glitches, or doc indexing issues ‚Äî happy to share what we learned (no spam, no sales, just actual fixes).

Let me know if you want a full map of common edge cases we‚Äôve mapped out across 16+ document pipelines. Would be glad to help. üöÄ

comments.body: Here‚Äôs my proposal for the advanced link settings (with the help of @PanchoutNathan) [FIGMA HERE](https://www.figma.com/design/XDjWHDLIiNY4mtpyj21EVK/DRIVE?node-id=11016-14581&t=NSgvHrrObiJFO9sK-1) Summary of the proposal: - We‚Äôre adding ‚Äúconnected‚Äù access, in addition to ‚Äúprivate‚Äù and ‚Äúpublic‚Äù - We‚Äôre introducing an advanced settings button for the link (previously, there was only the role‚Äîreader, editor, etc.) - A new advanced settings modal will include: role, expiration, password, and the option to create a one-time link The idea of creating and managing multiple links was explored extensively but ultimately rejected due to significant complexity. The current proposal has the advantage of requiring only one additional modal and maintaining the current link-sharing approach that users are becoming quite familiar with, especially in docs.

title: Range selection freezes when there are many items in the list

comments.body:
Hi,
Thanks for your issue.
We didn't have act on this feature but already discuss about it.
Does it mean implementing the webdav protocol ?

Thanks

Webdav is one way to do it. Its advantage is the simplicity, but it means that you have to be connected (Internet) to have access to your files.

The 2 other main ways are fuse and FS watchers. By fuse, I means creating a virtual disk, and implementing the synchronization of the changes + cache to edit offline: fuse is the technology to do that on Linux, and there are ports like winfsp on windows and macfuse on macOS. For FS watchers, the user have a normal directory on their computer, and the desktop client watches the changes in this directory with inotify (linux), fsevents (macOS), or ReadDirectoryChangesW (windows). The client can synchronize the files between the local directory and the Drive app.

With FS watchers, you have 2 hard problems: the synchronization, and watching the file system. Watching the file system looks quite easy at first, as inotify&co should be doing this job, but there are lots of edge cases. For example, the inode number on Linux (the identifier for the files) can be reused, so moving a file can be confused with deleting a file and creating another file.

So, the good answer depends of the level of convenience expected for the users vs the effort that can be spent on that task. I hope it helps.
[https://github.com/nextcloud/desktop](url) is using Webdav to sync. Maybe a good starting point?
For sure, compatibility with the Nextcloud client would be great, to allow working offline / backing up seamlessly
